trustfund:
TF037134-HONDURAS - RURAL AND MAIN ROADS PROJECT,TF036250-LAC REGION  - TRANSPORT SECTOR
            (HONDURAS, COSTA RICA, GUATEMALA)

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the First Urban Transport
            Project was satisfactory with an uncertain sustainability.
            Cancellation of some components (notably bus line of credit)
            meant that public transport objectives were not achieved.
            Key lessons learned follow: a) political commitment and
            changing priorities - projects need to secure political
            commitment to minimize the risk of component cancellation,
            and be short enough to safeguard against changing political
            priorities; b) institutional arrangements for implementation
            - consultation procedures should be improved, the creation
            of a professional Traffic Management Unit is essential,
            focus on institutional strengthening, and the planning
            agency should have a clear mandate; c) project design - the
            development of a line of credit must be taken to the
            "final scheme" stage at Appraisal; d) approach to
            detailed design at appraisal - it should include a
            representative sample of all types of measures proposed for
            the project and the co-ordination agency must seek consensus
            with the new authorities; e) supervision by BANOBRAS
            (National Bank of Public Works and Services) and the Bank -
            require a comprehensive review of the Project in relation to
            its objectives with a detailed action plan to recover
            overlooked components or policies, and Bank - agency
            dialogue must be continued; and f) La Venta - Chamapa Toll
            Road (LVC) - when a completed component's benefits are
            in doubt, the Bank should influence the borrower to seek
            remedial actions.
